proposals.reasoning: With no prior information, I want a low-drama, broadly acceptable starting pair that doesn’t reward anyone pushing hard to be included. Multiple players independently suggested Alice + Diana as a reasonable, measured team, and no one strongly opposed it. This gives us an early data point while keeping social pressure low, and we’ve already agreed not to over-clear either player even if the mission succeeds.

votes.comment: I’m on it, it’s widely supported, and it’s a low-drama info-gathering start without rewarding anyone pushing to be included.
This matches the low-drama, info-gathering pair I already endorsed, and rejecting it now would be inconsistent and draw unnecessary suspicion.
Solid low-drama opening pair, and consensus is decent with no strong objections.
Reasonable low-info Mission 1 team, includes me, and table consensus is fine; we can treat the result as light info without over-clearing anyone.
Low-drama, widely supported Mission 1 team; rejecting without cause would look suspicious this early.

discussion.content: With no info yet, I’d like to start as cleanly as possible: I’m happy to go on the first mission with someone who isn’t pushing too hard to be included. If anyone’s especially eager to be on Quest 1 right away, that’s a mild red flag for me.

I’d rather we don’t reward enthusiasm for Mission 1 either, so I’m fine with something like Alice + Charlie or Alice + Diana, since they’re both usually pretty measured early on. I don’t need to be on the first team; I’d rather see how people react to that kind of “safe” pairing.

I like the idea of starting with a low-drama pair, so Alice + Diana feels fine to me, and I’m happy to sit out and just read reactions for now. If you really want me on it, I’ll go, but I don’t think Mission 1 needs to be overthought.

I’m okay with an Alice + Diana team to start, but I don’t want us to treat it as “auto-clean” if it passes just because it looks low-drama. I’m also keeping an eye on how comfortable Bob is staying off early missions while still nudging the pairings.

I’m okay with Alice + Diana as a starter too, as long as we all agree not to over-clear either of them off a single clean result. If it somehow gets a fail, though, I’d lean harder on looking at who was strongly steering that “safe” pair.

proposals.reasoning: Keeping Alice and Diana as a core follows the table’s consensus after a clean first mission, and adding myself is consistent with my earlier stance that I’m willing to be tested. This team balances continuity (reusing a successful pair) with information gain by introducing one new member, without overfitting to whoever has stayed quietest or been most heavily lobbied for. It should feel like the most natural, low-drama extension of what worked on Mission 1 while still giving the group new data.

votes.comment: I trust keeping the M1 core and adding one new player for info; being on the team myself lets me directly control for at least one good and see how Bob behaves.
I’m on the team and it keeps the successful core from Mission 1 while adding new info.

I don’t love that the new addition is the person proposing the team; I’d rather see a variation that tests someone else (like swapping in Charlie or Eve) so the info we get isn’t tied so closely to leader self-selection.
Standard extension of the clean M1 core with one new player; we need early info and I’m on the team, so it’s a reasonable test despite Alice/Bob not being cleared.
My evil teammate is on the team and I’m off it, so this gives us a good chance to sabotage without drawing suspicion to me.

discussion.content: Given the clean first mission, I’d like to keep Diana and myself as a core for this round, and I lean toward adding someone who hasn’t said much yet—maybe Charlie—so we get new info without throwing out what’s already worked.
I like keeping Alice and Diana after a clean first mission, but I’d slightly prefer adding either me or Eve over Charlie so we don’t just auto-clear the first quiet person without testing them.

Sticking with Alice and Diana after a clean first mission makes sense, and I’d rather add someone who isn’t pushing to be on the team. From what we’ve seen so far, Charlie fits that better than Bob or Eve.

I’m fine keeping Alice and me from the clean first mission, but a 2‑person success doesn’t clear either of us, so I’d rather add someone who isn’t pushing to be included right now—Eve feels like the best info-gain third.

I’m good keeping Alice and Diana after a clean first mission, and between the options I slightly prefer adding Bob—early willingness to be tested feels a bit more trustworthy to me than staying in the background.

proposals.reasoning: Alice and Diana have already gone on Mission 1 together and produced a clean success with no fails. The only change that led to a fail on Mission 2 was adding Bob, so the safest way to secure this critical mission is to revert to the proven pair and keep the known variable off the team. At 1–1, I’d rather lock in the highest-probability success now and use Mission 4, with more information on the board, to test new players like Charlie or Eve instead of risking another mixed or experimental team here.

votes.comment: Safest high-success team: M1 Alice+Diana was clean, M2 only changed by adding Bob, so keeping him off now maximizes chance of success at 1–1.

Given table consensus and the fact I’m the only new variable on the failed team, blocking this now would just make me look defensive; let’s take the likely-success pair and sort out suspicions next round.
Safest option given M1 was clean with this pair and the only change on the failed M2 was adding Bob. At 1–1 I’d rather lock in the highest-likelihood success than introduce a new variable now.
I know I’m good, and Bob is the only new variable on the failed team, so Alice+Diana is currently the highest-confidence success from my perspective.
Consistent with prior discussion that this is the safest low-risk pair after the M2 fail with Bob added.

discussion.content: Given that adding Bob to the M1 pair caused the only fail so far, I really want Bob off this team. I’m happy with either running back me + Diana or trying me + someone totally new like Charlie to get more info.

If you’re convinced I’m the variable, then we should stop rerunning the exact same core—Alice+Diana tells us nothing new if it passes. I’d rather see something like Alice+Charlie this round so we actually learn who’s clean instead of just locking in assumptions.

Given we’re 1–1, I’d rather prioritize a likely success over new info, so I lean toward rerunning Alice + Diana instead of bringing the known “new variable” from the failed team back in. If we stabilize this round, we can afford to get more experimental on the next mission.

I’m really not loving Bob back on a team after he was the only change on the failed mission, so my preference is to rerun Alice + me for a solid success and then use Mission 4 to test someone like Charlie.

I’m fine keeping Bob off this one given he was the only change on the failed mission, so Alice + Diana looks like the safest pick right now, though we should be careful not to treat that as hard proof about Bob either way.

proposals.reasoning: Alice and I (Diana) are the only pair that has been on multiple missions together (M1 and M3) with 0 fails both times. The only failed mission was M2, which added Bob to that same core and produced exactly 1 fail, making Bob the prime suspect and someone we should keep off this team. For the third slot, the choice is between Charlie and Eve. Bob (the most likely evil) explicitly nudged toward adding Eve, which makes Eve slightly riskier by association. Charlie, on the other hand, already led a clean Mission 3 that included the Alice–Diana core and has been reasoning in line with a good perspective. Therefore, the safest and most consistent good-leaning team is Alice, Charlie, and Diana.

votes.comment: Alice+Diana are almost certainly good from two clean missions; the only fail was when Bob joined them, making him the likeliest evil. Between Charlie and Eve, Charlie is safer given Bob’s push toward Eve, so this is our best odds of a clean team.
I still slightly prefer Eve over Charlie as the third; I’m not fully convinced this is our safest combo yet.
This keeps the proven Alice–Diana core and avoids the risky Bob/Eve spots, so it’s our safest option.
Alice+Diana have two clean missions; the only fail was when Bob was added. Between Charlie and Eve, Charlie is safer, especially since suspected-Bob nudged toward Eve.
This team completely excludes both Bob and me, which is exactly what good would want given the current narrative; as evil I need to disrupt this ‘safe core’ from auto-winning.

discussion.content: Given Missions 1 and 3 both succeeded with just me and Diana, I’m heavily inclined to lock the two of us in and keep Bob off; I’d add either Charlie or Eve as the third, but Bob shouldn’t be on this team.

I agree I shouldn’t be on this one given Mission 2, but between Charlie and Eve I slightly prefer Eve, since Charlie led a clean Mission 3 yet hasn’t really put himself in a position to be tested on a larger team.

I’m fine locking in Alice and Diana again since that’s our only fully consistent pair so far, and given Mission 2’s fail plus Bob preferring Eve here, I’d rather we add me as the third than risk changing two slots at once.
I’m definitely keeping Alice and me locked in, and given Mission 2’s fail plus Bob nudging toward Eve, I feel a lot better about adding Charlie as the third here.

Given Missions 1 and 3, I’m comfortable saying Alice+Diana are our safest core, and I get why people are leaning Charlie over me—especially with Bob openly preferring me. If this team somehow still fails, though, we’ll need to be ready to revisit the assumption that the Alice/Diana pair is automatically clean.

evil_discussion.content: I lean pretty hard toward Alice as Merlin: she’s been steering core structure from the start, framed M2 to “keep Alice and Diana” as a default good pair, and then pounced on me as the obvious variable after the M2 fail in a way that feels more confident than the information strictly allowed. Diana’s tone reads more like a strong-but-cautious servant who’s updating off the table state rather than hidden info—she kept the Alice+Diana pair but still left room for doubt and “info-gain” later, which is how a non-Merlin often plays when they think they’ve stumbled onto a good core.

I’m mostly with Bob that Alice is the best Merlin hit: she consistently treated Alice+Diana as the “right” core from almost nothing, then snapped to “Bob off the team” after M2 with a confidence level that doesn’t match a normal servant’s uncertainty, and kept subtly framing every later team around that assumption. Diana feels more like a strong, reactive villager who’s anchoring to prior successes without over-claiming certainty, and Charlie’s been too deferential and info-light to be the one secretly driving the game, so I’d rank it Alice > Diana > Charlie for Merlin.

assassin_phase.reasoning: Alice consistently anchored on the Alice+Diana core from very early with more confidence than a normal servant should have, and after Mission 2 she immediately hard-framed Bob as the problem variable and kept him off all future preferred teams. Her steering of team structure and certainty about who was safe reads like someone with extra information, whereas Diana looks more like a strong but cautious servant and Charlie has been too passive to be secretly driving the game as Merlin.

post_game_reflections.self_assessment: I stayed consistently on teams that ended up being successful and kept my reasoning straightforward, which helped maintain trust in me as good. I could improve by pushing harder on analyzing the failed Mission 2 and more actively questioning Bob and Eve instead of mostly relying on others’ reads.

player_observations.Bob: Comfortable being on mixed teams and slipping a single fail into Mission 2 without drawing immediate, strong suspicion; tends to hide behind group consensus rather than leading accusations.
player_observations.Charlie: Played a very controlled, low-key information game as Merlin, nudging team selections toward safe configurations without making themselves an obvious target; rarely over-explained reads.
player_observations.Diana: Consistently aligned with successful missions and seemed naturally trustworthy, favoring simple, logical arguments over elaborate theories; comfortable taking leadership when given it.
player_observations.Eve: Stayed relatively in the background and relied on deduction in the assassin phase, but their final guess showed some overestimation of how much influence I had on team choices.

post_game_reflections.self_assessment: I managed to get a crucial fail on Mission 2 without immediately outing myself, but I didn’t do enough to sow lasting distrust between the good players afterward. I need to be more proactive in pushing alternative narratives and paying closer attention to subtle Merlin-like behavior, especially from quieter players like Charlie.

player_observations.Alice: Tended to trust and work with a small core group early, which made it harder to fracture the good team once that trust was established. Her play was straightforward and relatively transparent, which made her look more like generic good than Merlin.
player_observations.Charlie: Played a very low-key, non-dominant role while still consistently ending up on successful teams, which is classic strong Merlin play. He avoided overt accusations yet subtly steered team compositions, making his reads seem reasonable rather than magically accurate.
player_observations.Diana: Showed a preference for stability in team selection, reusing known-success teams, which strengthened good’s cohesion. She didn’t push hard theories, which made her look solidly good but not overly suspicious as Merlin, a pattern I should have exploited more by framing her as a safe but non-central good.
player_observations.Eve: The assassination on Alice suggests she was overweighing overt influence and visible leadership as Merlin indicators. Coordinating more explicitly about who seemed to be quietly but consistently right (Charlie) could have helped refine the assassination target.

post_game_reflections.self_assessment: I managed information carefully: I pushed just enough suspicion onto Bob after Mission 2 while subtly reinforcing trust in Diana and keeping Alice from looking too clean, which helped protect my identity. I could improve by creating a more believable arc of doubt on Diana earlier, so my strong confidence in the final team didn’t look quite as informed, and by speaking a bit less authoritatively at key moments to reduce the risk of late-game Merlin reads.

player_observations.Alice: Very trusting and consistent once she commits; she tends to lock in reads early and ride them through later missions, which can be great when correct but exploitable if misled early.
player_observations.Bob: Comfortable sitting in the middle of the pack and letting others drive the logic; as evil, he played fairly low-key and leaned on social trust instead of aggressively shaping the narrative.
player_observations.Diana: Plays with a strong cooperative tone and is willing to take leadership responsibility; she seems to value logical consistency and mission history more than table talk when deciding teams.
player_observations.Eve: As assassin, she focused heavily on social cues and visible confidence rather than detailed mission logic for her Merlin pick; she seems to favor bold, decisive reads over cautious, incremental deduction.

post_game_reflections.self_assessment: I stayed consistently pro-mission and helped build trust by anchoring the successful teams on Missions 1, 3, and 4. I could improve by pressing harder on Bob after the Mission 2 fail and by more actively driving the table discussion to narrow down evil earlier.

player_observations.Alice: Generally read as solidly good, especially after the clean Mission 1, but her inclusion on the failed Mission 2 made her temporarily suspicious. She stayed calm under that suspicion, which helped keep the team from overreacting and mis-clearing Bob too fast.
player_observations.Bob: Used the Mission 2 fail well to muddy the waters and shift suspicion onto Alice and me instead of himself. He stayed relatively low-key rather than loudly steering, which made his evil alignment harder to pin down until later.
player_observations.Charlie: Played a careful Merlin game, guiding team selections toward good outcomes (notably Missions 3 and 4) without being too obvious. His subtle pushes away from bad teams and lack of over-assertiveness helped him avoid being assassinated.
player_observations.Eve: Assassin play was focused and cautious, waiting for patterns in mission picks and table talk before making a guess. The final shot on Alice showed she was tracking who looked central to the successes, but she slightly overestimated how obvious Merlin’s influence was.

post_game_reflections.self_assessment: I coordinated reasonably well with Bob on Mission 2’s fail, but I over-indexed on Alice’s apparent centrality and underestimated how carefully Charlie was choosing teams without drawing suspicion. I should have scrutinized Charlie’s consistent presence on successful missions and his cautious, low-flash behavior more, rather than assuming Alice’s early leadership and inclusion meant she was Merlin.

player_observations.Alice: Took early leadership and played in a straightforward, transparent way, which made her look like a natural Merlin candidate; her style seemed open and non-paranoid, which effectively drew suspicion away from the real Merlin.
player_observations.Bob: Managed to get a clean fail on Mission 2 without creating too much blowback, blending his evil role into the narrative and not over-defending himself, which helped keep attention scattered.
player_observations.Charlie: Quietly influential: consistently ended up on successful missions and supported strong team compositions without loudly directing others, a subtle Merlin style that avoided dramatic tells while still nudging the table correctly.
player_observations.Diana: Appeared reliably good and trustworthy, often getting picked for teams and responding to outcomes in a grounded, non-theatrical way, which reinforced the credibility of the missions she was on and helped stabilize good’s narrative.
